an4.126:4.1: “Mendicants, these four people are found in the world.
an4.126:4.3: Firstly, a person meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
an4.126:4.4: In the same way they spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
an4.126:4.5: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
an4.126:4.6: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the pure abodes.
an4.126:4.7: This rebirth is not shared with ordinary people.
an4.126:5.1: Furthermore, a person meditates spreading a heart full of compassion … rejoicing … equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
an4.126:5.2: In the same way they spread a heart full of equanimity above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
an4.126:5.3: They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as an abscess, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self.
an4.126:5.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the pure abodes.
an4.126:5.5: This rebirth is not shared with ordinary people.
an4.126:5.6: These are the four people found in the world.”
